@CryptoAddict247 If this assertion proves correct, it could be a key trigger point for a correction because it is this surge in cyclicals relative performance that has driven the new bull market in the S&P500.  https://t.co/bX2ds5piov

@CryptoAddict247 The extremes in relative performance mirror the 'extreme' also seen in the PMI.  One thing about extremes is that they don't often last, and can often times represent a climax (or nadir).  So the risk is then that this chart - which looks very good btw - looks "too good"
@CryptoAddict247 The reason I highlight it is because the degree (pace and magnitude) of relative performance has become extreme.  Rule 1 for market analysts: look for extremes.

@CryptoAddict247 In this chart I show it overlayed against the ISM manufacturing PMI - a key economic cycle indicator for America.  It shows (perhaps unsurprisingly) a loose correlation.  In this sense it both reflects and confirms the strength seen in the economic cycle indicators...

@CryptoAddict247 tracking this relative performance of cyclicals vs defensives not only helps identify opportunities strictly within this space (e.g. short cyclicals, long defensives), it also serves as a market and economic indicator (economic due to cyclical sensitivity)

@CryptoAddict247 relative performance: this is the ratio of one index to another, tracks whether one is doing better than the other this case it is a group of cyclical sectors divided by a group of defensive sectors if the line goes up it means cyclicals are doing better

@CryptoAddict247 not sure which part, so here goes... cyclicals = stocks/sectors that tend to do well during an economic upcycle (and bad during a downturn) defensives = stocks/sectors that tend to just plod along regardless

@lighthousejerry The underlying plumbing of it is that it's supposed to be a means of exchange/payment system thing.  The collectibility aspect seems to be just a marketing ploy --> make the price go up and encourage viral adoption and maximize attention

@madronapartners possibly. Base case is I would charge in USD.  But am always flexible in payment method anyway so if someone wanted to pay using bitcoin I would most likely accept and just figure it out
@MindTheCurve Regulatory aspect is interesting, but most my clients have armies of compliance people so I just have to put up with regulatory burden
@andy_trott Yeah, none of those apply to me.  I do get that tho - it's like in the "old world" where cash was/is king for crims (cash is mostly not traceable, and is used for tax avoidance)

@babak57798788 traceability a non-issue for me (tho I get it may be an issue for others...). FX fees suck and I hate them, but then still have FX vol to deal with (e.g. selling the crypto coin to get proceeds to my base currency)
@jtk0621 yeah I can see the appeal to black market and "rogue regimes"

@martinfrogers Thanks, what would be particularly interesting would be a service where you could use a crypto currency as pure infrastructure i.e. instant transfer between buyer/seller from their FX to crypto to your FX (and with low fees). Still FX vol an issue...
@GammaticalError Interesting point. Might become an issue again soon if the Fed steps up hikes as the China property market rolls over...
@MistaBlue22 Thanks, pretty damning for what is basically the 'gold standard' of crypto coins (for now at least!)
@Jeronimoferrer ok, yeah so I don't have any of those issues where I'm domiciled, but I can see how it could be a viable alt in that situation

@TheVolawatcher I was getting at it from a payment system perspective... on that front gold would be waaay down the list - don't want someone dropping a lump of gold on my doorstep - esp.  if I need to use it to pay a bill to someone who only takes bank TT
@GammaticalError Indeed, in FX it's ALL relative
@Jeronimoferrer what about traditional bank telegraphic transfers?
@Andrew4562 Yeah anonymity isn't an issue with my business (B2B), I know my clients, a lot of the time have visited them in person before signing.

@CryptoGulch To be fair I'm mostly B2B so even using paypal is rare, but yeah I hate fees and if all else was equal would love to pay lower (ideally none!) fees... but all else is not equal as there's big FX vol (I would accept the Bitcoin and immediately sell it and buy my base currency)
@ThinkFinance999 Yeah the FX vol is massive - it would be like billing a client in Venezuelan bolivar
@EconomPic @dynamicvol "marginal speculative investment dollar" - an old term I used to use for referring to the cycles of speculation between assets in China

My biggest issue with crypto (and I may be missing something): as a business owner I don't see any practical advantage of Bitcoin vs paypal as a means of accepting payments (or IMT/TT for that matter!).
@matt_levine #MerryCrypto  - probably get a blow-off top after Christmas as all the new converts pile in (Christmas-gathering-inculcation)
@EconomPic @dynamicvol there's one theory that the euphoria in crypto is helping extend the equity bull run by diverting potential froth from the equity market
@IvanTheK yep. doesn't help that a few other headwinds are building for gold
